contentrichtext.text: [[Image:Chute de Montmorency.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Montmorency Falls in the summer.]] The '''Montmorency Falls''' ({{lang-fr|Chute Montmorency}}) are a large [[waterfall]] on the [[Montmorency River]] in [[Quebec]], [[Canada]].<ref>{{cite web | last =Professor Steven Dutch, Natural and Applied Sciences, University of Wisconsin - Green Bay | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Montmorency Falls, Quebec | work = Virtual Field Trips | publisher = | date = 19 January 2007 | url =http://www.uwsp.edu/geo/projects/geoweb/participants/Dutch/VTrips/Montmorency.HTM | format = 11500px | doi = | accessdate = 2008-11-09 }} highest in the province of Quebec </ref> The falls are located on the boundary between the borough of [[Beauport, Quebec City]], and [[Boischatel, Quebec|Boischatel]], about 12 km from the heart of old [[Quebec City]]. The area surrounding the falls is protected within the Montmorency Falls Park ({{lang-fr|Parc de la Chute-Montmorency}}). The falls, at 84 meters (275 ft) high and 46 meters (150 ft) wide, are the highest in the province of Quebec and 30 meters (98 ft) higher than [[Niagara Falls]]. The basin at the foot of the falls is 17 meters (56 ft) deep. The falls are at the mouth of the Montmorency River where it drops over the [[cliff]] shore into the [[Saint Lawrence River]], opposite the western end of the [[Île d'Orleans, Quebec|Île d'Orleans]]. The falls were given this name in 1613 by [[Samuel de Champlain]]. He named them in honour of Henri II, [[duc de Montmorency]], who served as viceroy of [[New France]] from 1620 until 1625. There are staircases that allow visitors to view the falls from several different perspectives. A [[suspension bridge]] over the crest of the falls provides access to both sides of the park as well as a spectacular view. There is also an [[Aerial tramway|aerial tram]] ([[Funitel]]) that carries passengers between the base and the top of the falls. In the summer the park hosts an international [[fireworks]] competition with the falls as a backdrop. The remnants of earthen forts built by [[James Wolfe|General Wolfe]] are located in the eastern portion of the park. They were constructed in 1759. The landings below Quebec City were repulsed by [[Louis-Joseph de Montcalm|General Montcalm]] at Montmorency Falls, costing the British 440 soldiers. Ultimately a successful assault was launched when Wolfe made a surprise attack by climbing the cliffs below the [[Battle of the Plains of Abraham|Plains of Abraham]]. The Falls were the site of a key scene between the lead actors in the 1947 film ''[[Whispering City]]'', which was filmed on location.<ref name="imdb_whispering_city">{{IMDb title|0039986|Whispering City}}</ref><ref name="internet_archive_whispering_city">{{cite web|url=http://www.archive.org/details/WhisperingCity|title=Whispering City (1947)|accessdate=2012-01-19}}</ref> The [[Ice Hotel (Québec)|Ice Hotel]] was located at Montmorency Falls for its first year. In his poem "[[Sleep and Poetry]]" (1816), [[John Keats]] says that human life is "a poor Indian's sleep / While his boat hastens to the monstrous steep / Of Montmorenci."<ref>http://www.bartleby.com/126/31.html</ref> ==Gallery''== {{cleanup gallery}} <gallery> File:QC View montmorency.JPG|A look at the surrounding areas, opposite the falls.
